awd_titl_txt: Chronologies and mechanisms of last glacial loess deposition in the Central Lowlands of North America
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance understanding of windblown silt (loess) deposition during the last glaciation across Midwestern North American landscapes.  Loess deposits are a vital ingredient to the region's rich agricultural soil and, with embedded fossil snails and ancient soils, are important paleoclimate archives. However, Midwestern loess remains poorly dated and disconnected from other climate and glacial records, limiting our understanding of the timing and drivers of loess deposition. New radiocarbon chronologies will relate deposition rate variations to past changes in sediment sources, climate, and ice lobe fluctuations in the Great Lakes region from ~ 25,000 to 18,000 years ago. This research will improve understanding of regional paleoclimate records and atmospheric dust budgets during this last glacial period. An interactive module on the Pleistocene Illinois landscape for an after-school enrichment program, STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Math), will introduce these important deposits to local students.
 
New, high resolution radiocarbon chronologies of loess, coupled with U-Pb zircon dating and trace elemental analyses of loess and glacial tills will provide detailed sediment sourcing history.  Stable oxygen and carbon isotope analyses of snail shells, along with species assemblages and stable oxygen isotope forward modeling, will aid determinations of the climatic context of changing loess deposition rates. Comparing these deposition rates with the timing of regional ice lobe fluctuations will permit better understanding of the relationships among glacier movement, climate, glacial sediment supply, and downwind loess deposition.

por.por_cntn:
Across the midwestern United States, a thick cover of loess (windblown silt) blankets the landscape and is a significant contributor to the region's rich agricultural soils. This project enhances our understanding of the timing and rate of loess deposition during the Last Glacial Maximum (~ 29,000 to 17,000 years ago), when much of the upper Midwest was covered with the southern lobes of the continental-scale Laurentide Ice Sheet. Much of the loess in the Midwestern USA was deposited during dust storms which entrained the abundant sediment in major river valleys that served as glacial meltwater sluiceways.  As part of this project, we tracked the pathways of source material for loess, including how meltwater sediment was derived from different glacial lobes of the ice sheet, the ultimate bedrock sources or terrains which were overrun by distant glaciers and contributing sediment from nonglacial river systems. A dataset of zircon grain ages led to new insights into the source of loess and the size of the Laurentide Ice Sheets during previous glacial periods.  In particular, the eastern portion of the ice sheet was found to be a present and an important source of downstream glacial sediment in glacial periods before the Last Glacial Maximum.  The various glacial lobes of the upper Midwest were found to be distinguishable by zircon ages among those sourced from the eastern Great Lakes, central Great Lakes, and Great Plains regions.  High resolution chronology from this project has also provided a basis to correlate the timing of rapid pulses in loess deposition with oscillations of the ice margin of the glacial lobes.  Such information, in relation to ice sheet extent and fluctuations, is extremely useful, as changes in the size of these past ice sheets has implications for past sea level and climate, but the details are not well known.

In another aspect of this project, we collected and identified numerous fossil land snails that were preserved in these loess deposits at several locations. Changes in species assemblages and the stable oxygen isotope ratios of these shells, combined with high resolution radiocarbon dating of terrestrial shells for age control, led to new information on the nature of warm season precipitation, temperature, and ecological changes during the Last Glacial Maximum. The data suggest a significant regional cooling as the ice sheet advanced into the Midwest, along with distinctive changes in precipitation, which suggests more organized storms tracking across the region during the warm season, due to the strong temperature gradient between the ice sheet and the ice-free land to the south. Finally, multi-centennial variations in loess sedimentation rate, documented at a loess site in Kentucky, appear to relate simultaneously to fluctuations in climate and the margin of the southern Laurentide Ice Sheet. This research helped train an underrepresented minority in Earth Science and we also developed and conducted a program on ice age geology for the local STEAM Studio afterschool program in Champaign, IL.
